Declaring that the influence of
the Johns Hopkins School of Hygiene extends into the farthest
provinces of China, Dr. Edward
H. Hume, dean and professor of
medicine in the Hunan Yale College of Medicine at Changsha,
China, struck a popular note when
he addressed the student body at
the assembly last Thursday.
The word "revolution" was the
keynote of Dr. Hume's speech. He
pointed out several instances of
revolution with which Americans
are most familiar, and then spoke
about the Boxer uprising in 1900,
in which an attempt was made to
stop western aggression in China.
During the revolt, a young corporal, who saw an American college student executed as the result of helping some missionaries
to escape, was converted to Christianity. Today the corporal is General Fong, who has a wide reputation as the Christian general, and
who is. one of the two leading generals in China.
The speaker linked the American
University Movement with these
revolutions, and showed to what
extent it is a revolution in the lives
of the Chinese, bound by superstition, fearful of western interference and control, and still somewhat restricted by the old educational system, which was abolished
in 1905. The leaders of the movement to establish branches of
American universities in China
were Elisha Goodman, of Amherst,
and Samuel Brown, of Yale, who
began their activities in 1832. Dr.
Hume was the first American physician to stay permanently in Hunan, a province which is especially
hostile to foreign enterprises.
Dr. Hume gave several examples of the superstition and great
learning which exist side by side
in China. Although they themselves have a medical knowledge
which is the product of several
thousand years' experience, the
thy Chinese are extremely superstitious, especially in regard to the
evil spirits, which they believe exercise a powerful influence over
the lives of human beings. For example, they will not allow the both'
of. a person who died away from
home to be brought home for burial because they fear evil spirits
will enter the dwelling with the
body. If possible, a dangerously
ill person is brought home to die.
This enabled Dr. Hume's hospital
to preserve for several years the
unusual record of no deaths.
Dr. Hume concluded his address
by expressing a desire to see more
American universities take up the
work now being done by Hopkins,
Yale, Princeton and a few others.
In the afternoon Dr. Hume gave
another address in the C. E. Hall
before a large audience, in which

other hand, are the national health
movement, social reforms, educational progress, and the elimination

Choice of a Career
From the Yale News
THE NINETY-FOUR

Someone, probably an insurance
agent, was quoted recently as saying
that from the mass of one hundred
college graduates one individual only
rose to the Polo and butler class, perilously near the top of the financial ladder. Five others became comfortably
off and found themselves after twenty
years at the small yacht and chauffeur
stage. The other ninety-four presumably congregate in the great section of
the American people who drive their
own Buicks to the golf club. In other
words, dreaming about being a rich
man is one thing, and making the grade
is something else again."
Yet the ninety-four presumably work
just as hard as the sumptuous six. Their
business is the axis on which a small
and uninteresting world revolves. They
have become devotees of the dollar
and when that fickle deity deserts, have
nowhere else to turn. Jammed in a
dull, straight rut of business they can
never leave the road and jump the fence
into finer fields of life. This, then, is
the portion of ninety-fur men out of
every hundred now on the campus.
The answer to the problem lies in
the proper choice of a career.

Between now and Commencement
we shall have something to offer on
the subject of "Careers." Watch for

pointed out several instances of

are most familiar, and then spoke
about the Boxer uprising in 1900,
in which an attempt was made to
stop western aggression in China.
During the revolt, a young corporal, who saw an American college student executed as the result of helping some missionaries
to escape, was converted to Christianity. Today the corporal is General Fong, who has a wide reputation as the Christian general, and
who is. one of the two leading generals in China.
The speaker linked the American
University Movement with these
revolutions, and showed to what
extent it is a revolution in the lives
of the Chinese, bound by superstition, fearful of western interference and control, and still somewhat restricted by the old educational system, which was abolished
in 1905. The leaders of the movement to establish branches of
American universities in China
were Elisha Goodman, of Amherst,
and Samuel Brown, of Yale, who
began their activities in 1832. Dr.
Hume was the first American physician to stay permanently in Hunan, a province which is especially
hostile to foreign enterprises.

learning which exist side by side
in China. Although they themselves have a medical knowledge
which is the product of several
thousand years' experience, the

body. If possible, a dangerously
ill person is brought home to die.
This enabled Dr. Hume's hospital
to preserve for several years the
unusual record of no deaths.
Dr. Hume concluded his address
by expressing a desire to see more
American universities take up the
work now being done by Hopkins,
Yale, Princeton and a few others.

other hand, are the national health
movement, social reforms, educational progress, and the elimination

Choice of a Career
From the Yale News
THE NINETY-FOUR

Someone, probably an insurance
agent, was quoted recently as saying
that from the mass of one hundred
college graduates one individual only
rose to the Polo and butler class, perilously near the top of the financial ladder. Five others became comfortably
off and found themselves after twenty
years at the small yacht and chauffeur
stage. The other ninety-four presumably congregate in the great section of
the American people who drive their
own Buicks to the golf club. In other
words, dreaming about being a rich
man is one thing, and making the grade
is something else again."
Yet the ninety-four presumably work
just as hard as the sumptuous six. Their
business is the axis on which a small
and uninteresting world revolves. They
have become devotees of the dollar
and when that fickle deity deserts, have
nowhere else to turn. Jammed in a
dull, straight rut of business they can
never leave the road and jump the fence
into finer fields of life. This, then, is
the portion of ninety-fur men out of
every hundred now on the campus.
The answer to the problem lies in
the proper choice of a career.
